Award.AwardTitle: Heinrich Event Iceberg Flux, Melting, and Ocean Circulation in the North Atlantic
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project generally aims to generate high-resolution data on a suite of deep-sea sediment cores from the North Atlantic Ocean and to conduct a comparison of the results with conceptual and computer models for the episodic production of major iceberg discharges. The researchers aim to produce a spatially systematic dataset of the concentration, provenance and flux of ice-rafted debris (IRD), derived from the North American Laurentide Ice Sheet (LIS) in an array of sites extending from west to east across the subpolar ocean, and south to the subtropics. These data will be used to test hypotheses regarding the genesis and subsequent distribution of melting icebergs associated with the Heinrich events of the last glaciation and to provide insights into the interactions of cryosphere and ocean circulation.

The catastrophic iceberg discharge (Heinrich) events that punctuated the last ice age were among the largest known interactions of the Earth's cryosphere, ocean, and climate. Although there is continued debate about their causes and consequences, in at least a subset of the events, the evidence is consistent with their likely influence on the salinity and stability of the subpolar Atlantic, significant weakening of the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC), cooling of the northern hemisphere, warming of the southern hemisphere, and shifts in the global hydrological cycle and large-scale atmospheric circulation and composition. Yet deposits associated with two of the six events originally identified during the last glaciation have very different sedimentary characteristics in the eastern subpolar North Atlantic, where they have most commonly been compared. This poses a problem for any single mechanism proposed to explain the events, requiring exceptions or contrasting explanations for different events.

The Broader Impacts involve advancing understanding of the cryosphere, ocean, and climate system. The project will support an early career postdoctoral researcher and several undergraduates in the research. Research participants will take part in a research cruise to recover new sediments as part of a collaborative effort that is aligned with the goals of international efforts to understand the Coupled North Atlantic-Arctic System. The Broader Impacts also involve outreach through collaboration with for New York City public high school teachers and students. Members of the project will participate in the biennial Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory Open House which draws thousands of visitors of all ages to the campus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to reconstruct past variations in iceberg discharge, sea surface hydrography and deep ocean circulation in the North Atlantic Ocean during the last ice age using proxy data from deep-sea sediment cores. We used a combination of existing cores from the repositories at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and the Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, as well as a set of recently acquired cores recovered from the Labrador Sea in order to explore these variations from the subtropical and sub-polar ocean. The reconstructions and the observed sequence of past events were used to test hypotheses regarding the mechanisms of abrupt oceanographic, climatic and environmental variability. Time series and spatial arrays of uranium decays series disequilibria allow the assessment of rates of deep water transport, deposition of ice-rafted debris, and the level of oxygenation and thus changes in carbon sequestration in the deep ocean over time since the last ice age.

During the course of this project we analyzed over one thousand samples from a suite of high quality deep-sea sediment cores at a number of locations extending from the Labrador Sea across the sub-polar North Atlantic Ocean and into the western subtropical gyre. Much of the research was accomplished by junior scientists who all acquired skills and experience that will contribute to their academic and professional development. This project helped support the research of two postdoctoral investigators who have now taken faculty positions as Assistant Professors, a PhD student who is now considering postdoctoral opportunities, a number of undergraduate research projects including three senior theses and five summer interns, and several high school students who have now enrolled in college. Project participants including the PI, PhD student and undergraduates participated in community outreach events at the Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory and in the New York City area. The project led to multiple conference presentations, including several by students, and twelve published and pending papers.

Our findings include evidence that a series of six catastrophic iceberg outbursts into the North Atlantic Ocean during the last ice age all emanated from an ice sheet on North American, with icebergs disgorged into the Labrador Sea and drifting southward before eventually spreading eastward across the sub-polar ocean as they melted. This result has the potential to resolve debates about the origin of these multiple iceberg discharge events, and also provides evidence of the location and magnitude of freshwater melt associated with them. The project results also confirm that substantial variations in the large-scale deep ocean circulation accompanied the iceberg discharges and abrupt climate changes in the North Atlantic region. In addition, evidence from an extensive spatial array of sediment cores reveals that levels of abyssal dissolved oxygen were lower, and therefore deep ocean carbon storage was greater, across the North Atlantic, especially within the eastern basin, at the peak of the last ice age. This finding indicates that the deep Atlantic played a significant role in the lowering of atmospheric CO2 during the last ice age.
